citation-title.titletext: Sovereign Reason: Autonomy and our Interests of Reason

affiliation.ce:source-text: Adam Cureton Lindsay Young Professor of Philosophy University of Tennessee, Tennessee, USA
Adam Cureton Lindsay Young Professor of Philosophy University of Tennessee, Tennessee, USA

abstract.ce:para: We often invoke reason, rationality, reasonableness, reasons, and related concepts in common sense. Despite what many serious thinkers claim, the reason of everyday life is far more substantive than cold logic or calculating self-interest. This book explores the idea that our power of reason includes an expansive set of governing abilities, motives, and principles. It develops this novel theory drawing on a wide variety of Kant's texts and highlighting themes in ordinary ways of speaking and thinking that have not been sufficiently investigated. The book's unifying idea is of an autonomous person who governs herself completely by reason. The Sovereignty Conception of Reason dramatically extends traditional Kantian conceptions of rational self-governance. We can use reason to govern our many mental powers, not just to make choices. We can legislate, execute, and adjudicate in ourselves all kinds of rational standards, not just moral ones. The Sovereignty Conception of Reason holds that our reason includes substantive interests in various things. Part of having a rational nature is to care about knowledge, enlightenment, happiness, solidarity, and other things for their own sake. The Sovereignty Conception of Reason also holds that our reason includes a principle of justifiability according to which mental acts of all kinds are required by reason if and because they are justifiable to rational people on the basis of their substantive interests of reason. The book contrasts the Sovereignty Conception of Reason with other prominent theories and explores rational principles concerning beneficence, coercion, deception, friendship, respect, happiness, and self-development.
